content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards are amended in section 32902 of title 49, United States Code to include non-passenger automobiles and classes based on vehicle attributes related to fuel economy. The Secretary shall ensure that non-passenger automobiles have an average fuel economy standard of at least 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. For passenger automobiles, fuel economy standards must be prescribed at least 18 months before each model year. The Secretary sets fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles each model year, based on what manufacturers can achieve. Separate standards may apply to different classes of vehicles. The Secretary sets fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles each model year, based on what manufacturers can achieve. For model year 2022 and beyond, the average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles must be at least 35 miles per gallon. Additionally, there is an alternative minimum standard for passenger automobiles in model years where standards are based on vehicle attributes. The fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles must be at least 35 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. There is also an alternative minimum standard of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles. The alternative minimum standard of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the projected average fuel economy applies to domestically manufactured passenger automobiles if the standard based on vehicle attributes would allow compliance with a less stringent average fuel economy standard. The manufacturer can choose to comply with a less stringent average fuel economy standard based on vehicle attributes during a transition period of the first 3 model years. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, with a transition period for passenger automobiles until a new standard is prescribed. The amendments made by this section will remain in effect until a standard for passenger automobiles is prescribed. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. Credits can be used in the same model years and the maximum increase in any compliance category is 1.0 mile per gallon. Transfers of credits are limited for certain categories of automobiles. The credit transferring program allows manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later. The term 'fleet' refers to all automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a specific model year. In the credit transferring program, manufacturers can transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. The term 'fleet' refers to all automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a specific model year, and the term 'compliance category of automobiles' refers to the 3 categories for compliance calculation. SEC. 3. FUEL CONSERVATION EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to educate US drivers on fuel conservation measures through a public information campaign using various media channels. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to educate US drivers on fuel conservation measures through a public information campaign using various media channels. The campaign will be cost-shared with the Secretary providing up to 50% of the funding and accepting private funds to supplement. Appropriations will be authorized as needed for implementation.
